newsitem.title: USA: NYMEX COB electric futures jump, Sept PV cuts loss.
newsitem.headline: NYMEX COB electric futures jump, Sept PV cuts loss.

text.p: NYMEX California-Oregon Border (COB) electricity futures jumped midday Thursday on a bullish combination of technical and fundamental factors, brokers and traders said.

"It's a little technical correction," said one Houston trader, adding forecasts of hot weather in the U.S. Northwest and expectation of lower hydroelectric output in September also pushed the COB half of the complex higher.
"After breaking out of $18.25, there's been a lot of buying," a New York futures broker said, referring to the September COB contract.
September COB was up 70 cents at $18.95 per megawatt hour (MWh) after hitting a near two-week high of $19.00. October COB gained 85 cents to $17.00.

September Palo Verde (PV) futures, moving in tandem with the strength in COB, were up 14 cents cents at $21.18 per MWh after talked as low as $20.30, October PV, in very thin volume, was up 80 cents at $17.00.
The Houton trader said ongoing softness in natural prices in West has pressured the September PV contract in early trading.
September natgas prices for delivery at San Juan, N.M., were quoted in the low $1.50 per thousand cubic feet range, down from the high $1.50 area on Wednesday close.
As of 1140 EDT, NYMEX said 50 COB and 37 PV PV contracts were sold.
September COB and PV contracts expire Tuesday, Aug 27.
